title: 2023 Everyday AI Hackathon
text:
ÌïúÍµ≠Ïñ¥ Î≤ÑÏ†Ñ





About the Hackathon
The Everyday AI Hackathon, in collaboration with Hugging Face and PseudoLab, is designed to introduce participants to Hugging Face technology. This event encourages the completion of a project where participants deploy a Hugging Face model based on their creative ideas. All kinds of projects are welcome!
The main emphasis is on collaboration over competition, enabling participants regardless of their technical proficiency to present a working demo and get a special badge. Through this hackathon we hope to foster a community of individuals passionate about Hugging Face, promoting mutual growth and learning.


How do I start?
The hackathon follows a straightforward process:

participants join in teams of up to three members,
create and deploy their projects on the Hub,
and describe their project in the README.md on Spaces.

Regardless of familiarity with Hugging Face, there‚Äôs a supportive environment, with tutorials and a dedicated Discord channel for communal learning and interaction. Dive in, learn, and collaborate!
For more information, please refer to the logistics guide and feel free to leave us a message.

title: 2023 Everyday AI Hackathon
section: How to Form Teams in Discord
text:
How to Form Teams in Discord
Discord offers an ideal platform for participants to connect, discuss ideas, and form teams for our hackathon. Below is a step-by-step guide to help you navigate the team formation process on Discord.

1. Join the Official Hackathon Discord Server
First and foremost, ensure you‚Äôve joined the official hackathon Discord server.


2. Familiarize Yourself with the Channels
Once you‚Äôve joined, take a moment to familiarize yourself with the various channels. There should be a specific channel dedicated to team formation, named #team-formation.


3. Introduce Yourself

In the #team-formation channel, post a brief introduction about yourself. Include:

Your skills and expertise
Your hackathon goals
What you‚Äôre looking for in team members


For example:

‚ÄúHi, I‚Äôm Alex! I specialize in NLP and have experience with Hugging Face. Looking for a frontend developer and a data scientist to form a team. Let‚Äôs create something amazing together!‚Äù



4. Connect with Others
Engage with other participants‚Äô introduction posts. If someone seems like a potential fit for your team, you can:

React to their message with a thumbs-up emoji.
Send them a direct message to discuss in more detail.



5. Use Voice Channels for Deeper Discussion
If you‚Äôre getting serious about teaming up, hop into one of the available voice channels to chat in real-time. This will help ensure compatibility and alignment of goals.


6. Confirm Your Team
Once you‚Äôve formed a team:

Announce your team members in the #team-formation channel: ‚Äú_Team [YourTeamName]: @Alex, @Jordan, @Taylor_‚Äù
Designate a team leader who‚Äôll be responsible for official communications during the hackathon.



7. Create a Discord Group (Optional)
You can make a private channel for your team via Discord Groups. This will give you a dedicated space to discuss strategies, share resources, and collaborate.


8. Stay Updated
Always keep an eye on #announcements or any other important channels. Admins or organizers will post important updates related to team formation or other hackathon processes.

Discord offers a seamless platform for participants to connect and form teams. By following the steps above, you‚Äôll find compatible team members and set the stage for a successful hackathon experience. Best of luck, and happy team forming!

title: Prerequisites & help
text: ÌïúÍµ≠Ïñ¥ Î≤ÑÏ†Ñ

title: Prerequisites & help
text:
Prerequisites
Before the Hackathon, please do the following (20 minutes). All software is free. If you are attending the Clinic, please do this in advance of the Clinic.

GitHub username

Create a GitHub account (if you don‚Äôt already have one) at https://github.com. Follow optional advice on choosing your username
Please provide your GitHub username here; this will allow us to add you to the cloud hackathon workspace.
Remember your username and password; you will need to be logged in during the workshop!

Hugging Face account

Create a Hugging Face account (if you don‚Äôt already have one) at https://hf.co/join
Remember your username and password; you will need to be logged in during the workshop!

Discord

Join our Discord workspace (invite sent via email). In the 2023-everydayaihack-projects channel, suggest a hackathon project idea/use case, and mention if you are looking for teammates to join. Read through other entries and comment on those of interest to you. On Day one of the hackathon we will hold a project pitchfest and finalize teams for the week.
Learn more about how we‚Äôll use Discord during the workshop

Google Meet

Be prepared to call into Google Meet using the link provided in the Discord 2023-everydayaihack-general Channel.

Get comfortable

Consider your computer set-up in advance, including an external monitor if possible. You will be following along on your own computer while also watching an instructor live-code over Google Meet (or equivalent), and will also want quick-access to Discord to ask for help and follow links.

title: Prerequisites & help
text:
Getting help
We will use Discord rather than Google Meet Chat as our main channel for help, since the conversations are preserved beyond a single call and since it‚Äôs easier to reply and have threaded conversations and post screenshots.

Discord
You will be invited to the PseudoLab Discord organization, where there is a growing community of ML experts. (New to Discord? See this Quick Start Guide). We have three private Discord channels for the Hackathon:
2023-everydayaihack-general: General channel is for announcements and general questions and communications.
2023-everydayaihack-projects: Projects channel is for for participants to pitch project ideas and discuss projects with the whole hackathon group. As teams form you can have direct messages with your team (and we can create new channels as needed).
2023-everydayaihack-help: Help channel is the place to get troubleshooting help: please paste error messages and post screenshots and we will help you by replying to your post.
To create a screenshot:

On your Mac - Screenshot
On your PC - Snipping Tool



Google Meet Breakout Rooms

During Tutorials Session
If you‚Äôd like to talk to someone and live-screenshare about your issue, please write in Google Meet Chat that you need help and we will move you into a breakout room with a helper.


During Team Hacktime
During the team project time, you will be placed in a Google Meet breakout room with your respective teammates to collaborate more easily. If you have questions as you work, post your question(s) in the Discord 2023-everydayaihack-help Channel and a helper will respond in that thread. If needed, a helper can also join your team‚Äôs Google Meet breakour room for easy screensharing, troubleshooting or to further discuss a question.

title: 2023 Everyday AI Hackathon
text:
ÌïúÍµ≠Ïñ¥ Î≤ÑÏ†Ñ




You‚Äôve worked hard, collaborated with your team, and developed something incredible. Now it‚Äôs time to show it to the world! Follow the steps below to submit your project for the Everyday AI Hackathon.

Submission Guidelines

Submission Period:

Projects can be submitted from October 20th to November 4th, 24:00. No submissions will be accepted after the deadline.

Project Format:

All projects must be hosted on Hugging Face Spaces.
Your project‚Äôs README.md should include a comprehensive overview, explaining the problem statement, solution, technologies used, and any other relevant information.

Team Information:

Clearly mention all team members‚Äô names and roles.
Designate a team leader who‚Äôll act as the primary contact point.




How to Submit

Fill Out the Submission Form:

Project Name: Choose a name that represents your project.
Project URL: Provide the link to your project hosted on Hugging Face Spaces.
Short Description: A brief overview of your project (max 200 words).
Team Members: List all members and their roles.
Contact Email: Provide the team leader‚Äôs email for correspondence.

Upload Additional Files (Optional):

If you have additional resources, documents, or slides that complement your project, upload them using the provided interface.

Review & Submit:

Ensure all information is accurate. Double-check URLs to ensure they‚Äôre working.
Click ‚ÄúSubmit‚Äù to finalize your project submission.




Post-Submission
Once submitted, you‚Äôll receive a confirmation email. Projects will undergo a review, and shortlisted teams will be notified regarding the next steps.
Thank you for being a part of the Everyday AI Hackathon! We‚Äôre excited to see your innovations and wish all participants the best of luck. If you face any issues during submission, please contact us through the Discord #support channel.

 Ï†úÏ∂úÌïòÍ∏∞

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
text:
ÌïúÍµ≠Ïñ¥ Î≤ÑÏ†Ñ
This tutorial will help you set up your JupyterHub (or Hub) with tutorials and other materials from our Cloud Hackathon github repository and connect your github account.

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
text:
Step 1. Login to the Hub
Please go to the Openscapes Jupyter Hub. Log in with your GitHub Account, and select ‚ÄúSmall‚Äù.


Note: It takes a few minutes for the Hub to load. Please be patient!

While the Hub loads, we‚Äôll:

Discuss cloud environments
See how my Desktop is setup
Fork the Hackathon repository at github.com
Discuss python and conda environments

Then, when the Hub is loaded, we‚Äôll get oriented in the Hub and clone the forked repository into our cloud environment.

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
text:
Discussion: Cloud environment
A brief overview about the NASA Openscapes Cloud Environment (following lessons from the Clinic).

Cloud infrastructure

Cloud: AWS us-west-2

Data: AWS S3 (cloud) and NASA DAAC data centers (on-prem).
Cloud compute environment: 2i2c Jupyterhub deployment

IDE: JupyterLab

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
text:
Discussion: My desktop setup
I‚Äôll screenshare to show and/or talk through how I have oriented the following software we‚Äôre using:

2i2c Jupyterhub (our main workspace)
Hackathon Repo <> Hackathon Book (my teaching notes, your reference material)
Zoom Chat
Slack

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
section: Step 2. Fork the Hackathon GitHub repository
text:
Step 2. Fork the Hackathon GitHub repository
‚ÄúHow do I get the tutorial repository into the Hub?‚Äù. There are 2 steps. The first is from GitHub.com to fork the tutorial repository so that there is a connected copy in your user account that you can edit and push changes that won‚Äôt affect the nasa-openscapes copy.
Go to https://github.com/nasa-openscapes/2021-Cloud-Hackathon and fork the repository.

Note: if you‚Äôve already done this in the Pre-Hackathon Clinic, you‚Äôll need to make sure you have the latest, following the daily setup instructions.

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
text:
Discussion: Python and Conda environments
Why Python?



Python Data Stack. Source: Jake VanderPlas, ‚ÄúThe State of the Stack,‚Äù SciPy Keynote (SciPy 2015).


Default Python Environment:
We‚Äôve set up the Python environment with conda.






Conda environment





name: openscapes
channels:
  - conda-forge
dependencies:
  - python=3.9
  - pangeo-notebook
  - awscli~=1.20
  - boto3~=1.19
  - gdal~=3.3
  - rioxarray~=0.8
  - xarray~=0.19
  - h5netcdf~=0.11
  - netcdf4~=1.5
  - h5py~=2.10
  - geoviews~=1.9
  - matplotlib-base~=3.4
  - hvplot~=0.7
  - pyproj~=3.2
  - bqplot~=0.12
  - geopandas~=0.10
  - zarr~=2.10
  - cartopy~=0.20
  - shapely==1.7.1
  - pyresample~=1.22
  - joblib~=1.1
  - pystac-client~=0.3
  - s3fs~=2021.7
  - ipyleaflet~=0.14
  - sidecar~=0.5
  - jupyterlab-geojson~=3.1
  - jupyterlab-git
  - jupyter-resource-usage
  - ipympl~=0.6
  - conda-lock~=0.12
  - pooch~=1.5
  - pip
  - pip:
    - tqdm
    - harmony-py
    - earthdata
    - zarr-eosdis-store




Bash terminal and installed software
Libraries that are available from the terminal

gdal 3.3 commands ( gdalinfo, gdaltransform‚Ä¶)
hdf5 commands ( h5dump, h5ls..)
netcdf4 commands (ncdump, ncinfo ‚Ä¶)
jq (parsing json files or streams from curl)
curl (fetch resources from the web)
awscli (AWS API client, to interact with AWS cloud services)
vim (editor)
tree ( directory tree)
more ‚Ä¶



Updating the environment
Scientific Python is a vast space and we only included libraries that are needed in our tutorials. Our default environment can be updated to include any Python library that‚Äôs available on pip or conda.
The project used to create our default environment is called corn (as it can include many Python kernels).
If we want to update a library or install a whole new environment we need to open an issue on this repository. We can help your teams do this during project hacktime.


corn üåΩ

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
text:
Step 3. JupyterHub orientation
Now that the Hub is loaded, let‚Äôs get oriented.






First impressions

Launcher & the big blue button
‚Äúhome directory‚Äù

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
section: Step 4. Clone the Hackathon GitHub repository
text:
Step 4. Clone the Hackathon GitHub repository
Now we‚Äôll clone the GitHub repository, using a git extension for the JupyterHub. Go to your github account, and navigate to the repository that you just created by forking from the Openscapes repository.
Click to copy the url for cloning the repository.

Now, go to JupyterHub and click on the git extension in the left panel and then click the blue button ‚ÄúClone a Repository‚Äù.

Then, paste the repository link to the forked repository that you copied from your github account into the ‚ÄúClone a repo‚Äù pop up window. Then click the blue ‚ÄúCLONE‚Äù button. It will take a few moments to clone the repository into your Hub.
Your link should look like https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/2021-Cloud-Hackathon. For example, the link is https://github.com/virdi/2021-Cloud-Hackathon. Note that it include your github username in the repo link.

Alternatively, you can use the terminal (command line) as per github workflows: first-time setup.
Once the repository is cloned, you will see a new directory in the ‚ÄúFile Browser‚Äù panel on the left named ‚Äú2021-Cloud-Hackathon‚Äù. In this directory, you have all hackathon material including the tutorials and this book to follow along during other Tutorials. You are all set.


REMEMBER: This is your copy (or fork) of the hackathon materials and jupyter notebooks. So feel free to make any changes to the content of this repository.

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
text:
Jupyter notebooks
Let‚Äôs get oriented to Jupyter notebooks, which we‚Äôll use in all the tutorials.

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
section: How do I end my session?
text:
How do I end my session?
(Also see How do I end my Openscapes session? Will I lose all of my work?)
When you are finished working for the day it is important to explicitly log out of your Openscapes session. The reason for this is it will save us a bit of money! When you keep a session active it uses up AWS resources and keeps a series of virtual machines deployed.
Stopping the server happens automatically when you log out, so navigate to ‚ÄúFile -> Log Out‚Äù and just click ‚ÄúLog Out‚Äù!
!!! NOTE ‚Äúlogging out‚Äù - Logging out will NOT cause any of your work to be lost or deleted. It simply shuts down some resources. It would be equivalent to turning off your desktop computer at the end of the day.

title: 00. Setup for tutorials
text:
Step 5. Tracking changes (Optional)
Now that you have forked and cloned the repository in your Hub, you can make changes (edit, add, and/or delete content) and track these files using git. In this step, we will provide an overview of how to use git using the graphical interface (the JupyterLab git extension).

Step 5.1. Configure Git (git config)
Configure git with your name and email address as shown here.
git config --global user.name "Makhan Virdi"
git config --global user.email "Makhan.Virdi@gmail.com"
Open a new terminal: File >> New >> Terminal

Configure git to store your github credentials to avoid having to enter your github username and token each time you push changes to your repository(in Step 5.5, we will describe how to use github token instead of a password)
git config --global credential.helper store


Step 5.2. Create a new file
Let‚Äôs create a new file: In the left panel on your Hub, click on the ‚Äúdirectory‚Äù icon and then double click on ‚Äú2021-Cloud-Hackathon‚Äù directory. Then, create a new file using the text editor in your 2i2c JupyterHub (File >> New >> Text File). Add some text to this file, for example: A test file. Save this file and rename it to test.txt.



Step 5.3. Track the changes to the new file (git add)
Click the git icon in the left panel. You can see that the newly added file is in the ‚ÄúUntracked‚Äù section. You can click the + icon next to the file name to let git track this file for changes.



Step 5.4. Commit the changes to the new file (git commit)
Now, you will see that the file is Staged, which means that git is ready to take a snapshot of this file (and the repository) with the changes that you made. This snapshot is called a commit. To commit the changes, add a note (called a commit message) by typing in the text box that say ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù.
Now, click the blue ‚ÄúCOMMIT‚Äù button to commit this change.

Note: A short message indicating the type of change to this file is a good practice. Optionally, a longer description may be added to the ‚ÄúDescription‚Äù field.




Step 5.5. Transmit committed changes to your github (git push)
At this stage, you have committed the changes to your git repository on your Hub. However, these changes are still on your Hub and needs to be transmitted to your repository on github (so that both the local copy on the JupyterHub and the remote copy on github are in sync).
As seen in the picture below, the git extension indicates (with an orange dot on the cloud icon) that it is ready to push your changes to the remote (remote = your repository on github.com). To push to github, click the cloud button with an up arrow (circled in red in the picture).

When you push for the first time, it will ask that you input your credentials. You will need to set this up with your Personal Access Token (PAT), explained next.


Step 5.6. Setup your Personal Access Token (PAT)
When you see the following screenshot, GitHub is asking for you to input your credentials. (Note: you see this screenshot when you have committed work to push to GitHub.com, as detailed above).

The git extension in the Hub is prompting you to enter your github.com credentials. Enter you github.com username and a Personal Access Token (PAT); DO NOT use your password.
To create a PAT, visit https://github.com/settings/tokens/new and create a new token with the permission as per the image below and specify its validity for 90 days.

IMPORTANT: You will see this token only once, so be sure to copy this. If you do not copy your token at this stage, you will need to generate a new token.

Once you generate the token, copy it and paste in the Hub window that prompted you to enter the ‚ÄúPersonal Access Token‚Äù.

Git will show a message at the bottom right telling that the changes were ‚ÄúSuccessfully pushed‚Äù. Also, you will see that the ‚Äúcloud icon with an up arrow‚Äù no longer has an orange dot, indicating that there are no more committed changes to push to the remote (github.com).

Note: You have configured git extension to store your credentials. You will not be prompted for your login/token again!


That‚Äôs all. You can use the same workflow (add > commit > push) for any other new or modified files!


Note: If you are comfortable with the command line, you can use the Terminal (In Hub, New > Terminal) and follow the steps outlined in the Clinic section.

title: 2023 Everyday AI Hackathon
text:
ÌïúÍµ≠Ïñ¥ Î≤ÑÏ†Ñ





Tutorials Overview
The success of our hackathon participants is of utmost importance to us. To ensure everyone has the tools and knowledge needed to create innovative projects, we are in the process of curating a series of tutorials tailored to various aspects of the hackathon. Whether you‚Äôre a beginner getting your feet wet or an experienced developer looking for advanced techniques, our tutorials will be designed to cater to all proficiency levels.


What to Expect

Getting Started

Platform Orientation: Understand the basics of the tools and platforms we‚Äôre using in the hackathon.
Setting Up Your Environment: Step-by-step guides to ensure your development environment is hackathon-ready.

Hugging Face 101

Introduction to Hugging Face: A beginner‚Äôs guide to understanding the Hugging Face ecosystem.
Deploying Your First Model: Learn how to get your model up and running with Hugging Face.

Advanced Techniques

Optimizing Model Performance: Tips and tricks to get the most out of your models.
Integration with Other Platforms: Guides on how to integrate Hugging Face with other popular tools and platforms.

Collaboration and Teamwork

Best Practices for Team Collaboration: Ensure smooth teamwork and efficient collaboration during the hackathon.
Version Control and Collaboration with Git: A guide on how to use Git for team projects.



We‚Äôre actively working on producing these tutorials and will be releasing them in the coming weeks. We encourage participants to regularly check this section for updates. If there are specific topics you‚Äôd like to see covered, please let us know in the #support channel on Discord.

title: Notebooks for live-coding
text:
ÌïúÍµ≠Ïñ¥ Î≤ÑÏ†Ñ
Templates of all tutorials ‚Äî .ipynb notebooks with code removed ‚Äî are available at:
https://github.com/NASA-Openscapes/2021-Cloud-Hackathon/tree/main/tutorials-templates.
Please open these tutorial templates in our JupyterHub to follow along and live-code with the tutorial lead.
